description: CS/IS 112 is a course in programming computers using the Java programming language, which includes defining the problem, flowcharting, writing, executing, and debugging application programs, and program documentation. Lecture 2 hours/ Laboratory 3 hours.
transfer_credit: Transfer Credit: CSU, UC, USC (C-ID COMP 112)

description: CS/IS 130 is a course in programming, algorithm development, and problem-solving using both object-oriented and structured approaches. It includes a study of syntax and data structures with applications in science, engineering, and industry. This course is suitable for students planning to transfer or those wishing to develop a marketable skill. Lecture 3 hours.

CS/IS 151 is a programming course in Python designed for individuals interested in becoming programmers or those with a curiosity for graphics and Graphical User Interface (GUI) programming. Python is a versatile language widely used in both business and game development. The course covers fundamental Python concepts and reviews essential computer science principles, including data types, decision structures, loops, functions, object-oriented programming, and introduces some basic graphics and GUI concepts. It offers a comprehensive foundation for Python programming and its real-world applications.
offered: Course Typically Offered: Spring (Every Other Year)

description: CS/IS 240 introduces the concept of cloud computing, a transformative shift in IT that transitions from traditional on-premises computing infrastructure to scalable and flexible cloud systems. This course offers a comprehensive foundation in cloud computing technologies, equipping students with the skills to evaluate and assess both the business and technical advantages of cloud computing and cloud applications. Hands-on training is an integral part of the course, with labs included to provide practical experience.

CS/IS 135 is a course in programming using the C/C++ languages, with applications in real-time, business, and image processing systems, as well as systems programming. The course covers types, operators, control flow functions, object-oriented programming, classes, data abstraction, program structure, pointers, and arrays through programming assignments. Lecture 2 hours/Laboratory 3 hours.
transfer_credit: Transfer Credit: CSU, UC, USC (C-ID CS 122)

description: CS/IS 137 prepares students for C++ programming in the workplace and other real-world environments. The course focuses on advanced object-oriented programming concepts needed for modern programs, as well as other advanced topics such as templates and generics, files and streams, and operator overloading. Students will have the opportunity to engage in advanced projects within the course's scope. Lecture/Demonstration 4 hours.
offered: Course Typically Offered: Fall (Every Other Year)

description: CS/IS 139 is a hands-on course where students work with programs to develop a comprehensive understanding of Java concepts in an interactive environment. The course involves creating and testing stand-alone applications and network applets across various operating systems and hardware platforms. Lecture 2 hours/Laboratory 3 hours.

MATH 103E is the first of a sequence of three courses combining the subject matter of analytic geometry and calculus. Functions and their graphs are studied with special attention to differentiation, limits, rules and integration using various techniques. The calculus of inverse functions and transcendental functions as well as applications of differentiation is also covered. Lecture 5 hours.
prerequisites: Placement is based on academic background or satisfactory completion of MATH 110 or 110B.
transfer_credit: Transfer Credit: CSU, UC, USC. (C-ID MATH 210)

description: MATH 104E is a study of techniques of integration, indeterminate forms, applications of integration, differential equations, the calculus of parametric equations, polar coordinates, and conic sections, and the study of infinite sequences and series. Lecture 5 hours
transfer_credit: Transfer Credit: CSU, UC, USC. (C-ID MATH 220)
